title: A Stroll Through Trendy Yaletown
reviews: I don’t tend to patronize Yaletown very often, which is kind of funny given the hotel I usually stay at is just a couple blocks away. Why is that, I wonder? I consider myself a foodie and history buff; thus, you’d think Yaletown would be a regular haunt of mine; however, it’s rarely on the itinerary whenever I’m in the city. Maybe I’ll have to work at changing that? After all, this neighbourhood is rife with history and remains home to some of Vancouver’s best restaurants. How could one resist that?From a geographic perspective, Yaletown is typically framed as being east of Homer Street, between Robson Street and False Creek (see my earlier reviews of both on this site). In that respect, Yaletown is a fairly compact neighbourhood, though it is quite densely populated thanks to the new-ish high rise towers along the waterfront. These rather pricey living spaces have unfortunately resulted in The Travel tagging Yaletown as “safe [but] snobby,” which I don’t think is a fair characterization because the neighbourhood certainly is NOT “snobby.” It’s chic and a little up-scale, yes, but remains just as friendly as other areas of Vancouver.One of the most significant things I appreciate about Yaletown is its history. In its infancy, it was primarily a warehouse district and shipping area for trains; in fact, it was once the Western terminus for the CP Railway. In the early 20th century, when rail started giving way to trucking, Yaletown remained in a sort of stasis until Expo ’86 arrived. When Vancouver played host to the World’s Fair, the waterfront along False Creek – including sections of Yaletown – housed many of the venues for this historic event. The Expo, then, not only improved Vancouver’s profile, but also provided the impetus for redeveloping and reimagining Yaletown.Indeed, it wasn’t long after the Expo concluded that Yaletown began to see something of resurgence. Many of the warehouses and brick edifices were transformed and re-purposed into office space, residential lofts, cafes and boutique shops. The restaurants, in particular, highlight this wonderful synthesis of the classic and the modern: Most are situated in redbrick warehouses that were built with exterior platforms originally used to load and unload trains. In the current day, these platforms now function as year-round patios. Personally, I love it when we can incorporate our history into the present so seamlessly!Speaking of restaurants, as already noted, Yaletown is home to some of Vancouver’s best:•   Blue Water Café (Was ranked #1 on TripAdvisor for the longest time, but still remains in the top 10. It’s also on my restaurant bucket list!)•   Bistro Sakana (An excellent sushi restaurant that specializes in aburi sushi. Very close in quality to Miku!)•   Cactus Club (Vancouver-based chain that needs no introduction. They have locations all over the place and are consistent across the board . . . also home to some of the most beautiful servers ;) haha. Some of you may get that reference)•   Grand Chinese Yaletown (Home to some great casual, and slightly upscale eats)•   The Keg (classic steakhouse)•   OEB Breakfast Company (Originating in Alberta, OEB is known for their unique breakfast/brunch options. Lobster crepe, anyone?)•   Bake49 (The double fromage cheesecake takes dessert to a whole new level!)There are a whole host of others, of course, so do take the time to amble about Yaletown before making your gastronomical selection!Beyond restaurants, Yaletown does offer a number of recreational activities. One could spend hours tootling about the brick walkways and taking pictures of the heritage structures, for example. Then there are also the boutique shops, which attract many. Or, if you want to escape the cityscape, Yaletown is also home to George Wainborn Park and David Lam Park, both of which run along the ever-popular Seawall, and provide lovely views of False Creek.Heritage meets modern, indeed. As I write these words, I feel inspired to visit this area more often. The living heritage is cool, but the restaurants are most enticing! Now, do yourself a favour and check out this “chic” neighbourhood and enjoy!

title: *** Great Hip Neighborhood **
reviews: Yaletown is one of the Chicest  neighborhood with down town Vancouver , a lot young people live here  ,fun , hip place , ,fine dinning  restaurants all around the area ,many out door terraces ,lot of old building ,Yaletown is bordered between Homer Street ,Robson Street and Flase Creak ,short walking distance to sea walk ,where great place for walking and Cycling ,also the David Lam Park , for family fun ,of course the B.C place ,Rogers arena ,and the 24 hours Casino  ,lovely Parq hotel ,well unique shopping for fashion and boutiques ,

title: Close (Just About) Everthing
reviews: Newcomers to Vancouver will find Yaletown a great base from which to visit many of the sights in downtown Vancouver. While Stanley Park and Burrard Inlet might be some distance away, I find I can walk in various directions to BC Place (NE), Granville Entertainment District (North), West End (NW) or, best of all, False Creek to the south.This compact high density residential neighbourhood includes some great parks along the seawall, and some well preserved historical icons. Locomotive 374 sits in the original roundhouse in what used to be an enormous railway yard, while the boxcar height loading docks for the warehouses are now utilized as patios for the restaurants. Skytrain station right in the middle of the neighbourhood, so leave the car at the hotel

title: A neighborhood to stroll, eat, and discover boutiques
reviews: We love walking in and around the Yaletown area and discovering new and old shops, restaurants and boutiques. We always have fun people watching.

title: Great to get out and walk around
reviews: Awesome place to get out and walk about one of the older parts of Vancouver.  Great access to False Creek and there are restaurants for every type of pallet.  If you are a photographer, there is a lot of architecture to take pictures of.   Even walkable and worth a visit in the rain.

title: Excellent Area of Vancouver
reviews: Yaletown is an excellent Hop On Hop Off area to stop.  There are a lot of different restaurants from which to choose.  It is a beautiful area with residential and shops.

title: Well to do residential area
reviews: We walked through here during the day on a weekday on our way to Granville Island. From what we could gather it is a well to do residential area with some nice restaurants and a pretty waterfront area. We enjoyed walking along the waterfront.

title: It comes to life at night
reviews: Yaletown is a clean tidy area of Vancouver.  It is good to walk around.It comes to life at night and has a very wide selection of bars and restaurants.

title: Great walking venue
reviews: Yaletown was just a ten minute walk from our hotel. We were able to stroll to dinner each evening and had a lot of different restaurants to choose from for our meal.  The vibe of the neighborhood was eclectic!

title: Worth the Visit!
reviews: Lot's to see and do! Shopping or dining if you still have some money go to the casino! Travel by foot or car plus the option of using transit.

title: Yaletown restaurants
reviews: Loved walking around Yaletown. Great selection of restaurants all in a row. Relaxing and fairly uncrowded area. Good coffee shops and food market as well.

title: Clean, Tidy Area
reviews: Definitely the more residential area of Vancouver. Not a lot to see, but a very clean tidy area with a good selection of restaurants.

title: Prime Real Estate
reviews: Yaletown is sort of like a big slice of pizza with the rounded edge of the crust being its frontage on False Creek.  Between False Creek itself and the soaring high rises are some delightful little parks (David Lam and Coopers); we especially liked the very pleasant walking trail along edge of False Creek's wall,Ferries run regularly across False Creek so commuters (and tourists) can easily get across False Creek from Yaletown.  There are Public Art displays and a cautionary reminder (blue stripes on bridges, poles, etc.) that forecast water level rises once global warming gets in full gear.The apex of that slice of pizza is (generally) Homer and Nelson.  The fantastic Roman Coliseum Public Library Plaza is near by and Yaletown is also very close to B.C. Place/Rogers Arena.  Yaletown has distinctive light post banners with their distinctive logo: a white maple leaf on a field of red.Since 1986, this has been an urban regeneration success story and it is now one of the most densely populated (and desirable) neighborhoods in Vancouver.  Those warehouses and industrial entities have been re-imagined into lofts, trendy restaurants and bars.  The face of Yaletown varies depending upon the different characteristics for the separate parts of Yaletown.

title: Love this area
reviews: My new favorite area in Vancouver!  Stayed here in the lovely opus hotel!  Excellent and safe.  Lots of really great restaurants and shops.  Super trendy.

title: Pre-ten-tious but fun.
reviews: Many excellent restaurants and bars.  Hang  out just to watch the Pretty People.  Cool architecture (for a western Canadian city), fun narrow streets.  Best in the evening on a Thursday through Saturday.  Prepare to be judged!

title: HISTORICAL DISTRICT
reviews: Yaletown is home to many of Vancouver's trendiest restaurants, bars and hip shopping. It is an historic district with art galleries.

title: The New Town
reviews: We spent some time to learn about the transformation of this railroad and warehouse area to the modern city.  It's a big success with terrific modern architecture and full of life and places to go and eat and drink.  And to the side is False Creek and the Aquabus!

title: Loved this area
reviews: My hotel was on the edge of Yaletown and I walked a fair bit of the area. It has a lot of great restaurants and arty shops - very stylish. It’s also a stop on the aquabus route. At certain points you can pick up free Yaletown WiFi which was helpful.

title: Amazing place
reviews: A lot of enough alternatives to eat and have a good time in the company of friends this is a very good option to visit in Vancouver

title: Interesting Change: Yaletown
reviews: We are currently traveling through the West of Canada. We started in Vancouver. It is not the first time being here but we we don't remember this area was here 10 years ago. A nice are not only for tourists but also locals who spend their time in the shops, restaurants, bars and pubs. Just another nice area and another reason to visit Vancouver again. Don't miss it.

title: lovely little neighbourhood
reviews: its nice when you are staying on the wildness of granvile st and then you walk 10 mins to the water and come here. there are lots of really nice restaurants and places to grab a drink, outisde seating which we really love. lots of little healthy cafes, shops, and a great spot to grab something to eat and people watch

title: Bustling New Town
reviews: This part of downtown was recently re-developed with a forest of skyscrapers, so lots of people live here.  It can be bustling.  Fun and interesting and safe.

title: Walk around Yaletown
reviews: Love the buzzing life, its cocktail lounges, restaurants, retro boutiques, transformed warehouse buildings, the friendly and busy atmosphere. I never miss a chance to takemy visitors there.

title: The life of the night...if you have a ride back
reviews: I enjoyed my time here--the nightlife, the food, the bars, and the clubs. I would have given this place a solid five stars if it had a more efficient and accessible mode of transformation. I  was extremely shocked when I opened my Uber and Lyft app only to find out these two services were banned from Vancouver. I brought my own car to Canada but if you want to have a couple of drinks and cannot drive back you have to rely on public transportation. The way the transportation system works is you basically have to walk a while for you to reach a metro and or a bus station. Public transportation is not as abundant as you would see in cities like D.C., New York, or even Mexico City where you can find a metro station in almost every single block. This is very inconvenient when you simply want to call a car and go to your final destination without having to make transfers in the metro, take another bus, and walk additionally. I did try to call a cab, but the cabs are very expensive and can deny you service because your destination is out of their range of where they can drive. It's just absurd to me how a modern city can have a terrible transportation system.

title: History meets Funky
reviews: This area was originally warehouses close to the western terminus of the CPR - hence the large patios, which were originally loading docks at box car height. Perhaps a younger generation will find some enjoyment in the plethora of bars and chain restaurants, but I, for one, would prefer to walk a few blocks and enjoy the serenity of False Creek.

title: Serenity in the City
reviews: Saturday afternoon... Yaletown was definitely vibrant--as opposed to crazy-tourist-busy, yet we found several on-street parking spots. In fact, the entire area felt like an oasis in the middle of the city. We went up and down Hamilton Street and found myriad restaurants, many little shops, and a good number of high-end "beauty and personal care" service providers including hair salons, nail salons, and massage establishments. This is definitely a good area in which to wander. (It also appears to be a nice place in which to live.)

title: History in modernity
reviews: I dropped by this place out of curiosity only to discover a stack of restaurants and service providers in a rejuvenated historical area that used to be a warehouse area. It has many pubs and eateries as well as service providers and unique retail outlets. The whole area is really "red" in colour of the Old style architecture. nice place for a stroll.

title: Streets filled with tons bars and restaurants
reviews: Great part of town just to walk around. Loads of bars and restaurants, mister artisan ice cream was a must stop for us and worth visiting the area by itself.

title: Nice residential area for young and educated people!
reviews: One of latest developments in Vancouver, with many appartments to choose from, easy access to city centre and public transport including Skytrain and Canada Blueline, it has a nice seawalk and many restaurants!

title: Interesting area to visit.....
reviews: We spent most of the day touring the Yaletown area.   From our hotel we walked down Davie Street to the Roundhouse, along Pacific Street, then up on Homer Street to the Robson Street area.   It is an interesting section of Vancouver to visit; lots of stores, restaurants and very new & modern high rise buildings.  (Unfortunately, like all major cities, Vancouver has a homeless problem and the area close to Granville Street has some homeless living on the street.)If you like photography, there are some excellent areas to photograph.  (In some way, Yaletown reminded me of the SOHO area in downtown Manhattan.)  If you’re in the area and have some time, please consider going there.

title: Lots of restaurants and good atmosphere
reviews: Yaletown was only a few minutes walk from our hotel and we found it was a good option for an evening meal. There are plenty of restaurants to choose from and it’s a pleasant area for an evening stroll.

title: Classy !!
reviews: And not just because we stayed in at 888 Homer street - but there is something for everyone here. It's a bit peculiar really in that you don't see the throngs of people on the streets as you might on Robson or Granville and suchlike but as soon as you enter a bar or restaurant in Yaletown they're all full - amazing but I have to say always with a good atmosphere throughout.We enjoyed our time here and will be happy to return - great place as a base.

title: New Neighborhood
reviews: After years of redevelopment, this neighborhood is now a forest of modern high rise apartments.  Some stores and restaurants, mostly catering to the residents.  Not far from downtown.

title: Great area
reviews: It's a nice walk along the water. Neat place with bunch of restaurants abound. Just love this area. There's David Lam park that affords a respite from the busy city. Stroll through Davie to soak in the urban feel

title: Area For food and drinks
reviews: Streets of warehouse style buildings full of restaurants, bars and large patios. There’s also boutique stores and salons and worth a look around.  Free wi Fi all around the streets too.

title: Too much hype
reviews: This district is over-hyped, over-priced, and over-rated. There are many hipster restaurants in Yaletown, but the sidewalks are hard to negotiate in high heels, and all the warehouses and old buildings look and feel like they could be safer.

title: Brilliant choice for a multi-layered wedding
reviews: We attended a wedding in their loft on the weekend. With the configuration of rooms in the lift, it was perfect for 80-90 people, private room for about 50 for the wedding & dinner, then wonderful to open up the doors and welcome 50 more to party & dance. Acoustics were a little loud. The bar was easily accessible; seating plentiful & dance floor wonderful. Life-sized horse on the side made an interesting conversation piece. Bar staff were wonderful; food on appetizer bar was regularly replenished & empty glasses were carefully & regularly removed. Great for a multi-stage event.

title: Nice, but Olympic has more to offer except at night
reviews: The area is nice and the buildings are interesting but all modern. There are, in my mind, far more interesting areas of the city that are more welcoming, have better views and are more exciting. This would be great if you had extra time on your vacation to just wander.

title: Shops and restaurants
reviews: It seems like a former industrial area that has been converted to residential. And a successful residential area must have shops and restaurants. Plenty of very good ones here.Like other neighborhoods, there is a homeless persons issue here.

title: Mainland Street has all the action.
reviews: My first time in Yaletown yesterday late afternoon despite several prior visits to Vancouver.A short ride on the Sky Train from Waterfront and Mainland Street is literally next door to the Station.Once a warehousing and industrial area, Yaletown, and Mainland Street in particular, has been regenerated as a “happening place”.Local Brewing Companies offer their range of craft beers in either their own F&B outlets or through other restaurants and cafes lining one side of the street. Shops and retail outlets line the other side.I found an interesting Sports Bar where I enjoyed some locally made Pale Ale before meeting a friend / ex colleague who had made alternative dinner plans for us.Yaletown is definitely worth a visit.

title: Nice Part of the City
reviews: Our hotel was near here and the concierge suggested we walk through the area - glad we did. It is a good example of a part of a city that has re-invented itself. Older buildings have been repurposed for restaurants and shops. It is now a trendy part of Vancouver. If you are taking the ferry over to Granville Island take a walk through this part of town to the Yaletown Dock.

title: neat little hide away in the city
reviews: funky stylish part of younger set ,in downtown, had a great meal at Rodney's, sea food of course, waiting long time to get in, then rush to finish meal though not cool

title: What a charming place
reviews: We visited Yaletown on our trip to Vancouver recently.I just loved the atmosphere of old industrial buildings revamped into restaurants and cute little boutiques.Definitely worth a walk through and next time we are hoping to dine there for dinner. I can just imagine how nice that must be, sitting in one of the outdoor platforms of a restaurant on a warm summer evening.

title: Great vibe at Yaletown
reviews: You'll enjoy the vibe at Yaletown. Close  to Rogers Arena. It's two streets of renovated dockyard buildings well set up for walking,  browsing boutiques and speciality stores. Great eateries from a casual sports bar for relaxed drinks and nibbles to seafood and oyster bars or restaurants for a special night out.

title: Don't miss the seawall....
reviews: ...because, other than that, this is merely a high density residential neighbourhood with some touristy shops, bars, and restaurants.

title: Lots of New Apartments
reviews: Yaletown has become a forest of high-rise apartments and all that comes with it, restaurants, grocery stores.  Pleasant density, but a bit lacking in charm.

title: Yaletown is a stylish, historical district
reviews: My wife and I walked all around Yaletown one afternoon. Sitting along the south side of the downtown Vancouver peninsula, Yaletown is bordered by Homer Street, Robson Street and False Creek. It is filled with residential loft spaces, sidewalk cafes, cool restaurants, unique shopping, and leafy parks.

title: Nightlife
reviews: This neighborhood is full of average to luxury bars and restaurants and is a main attraction for nightlife.

title: It is all about the food
reviews: There are 22 restaurants in a 4 square block radius. Check your guide before choosing one. It is open into the night with lots of Hipsters

title: Trendy Urban Neighborhood with Solid Restaurants and Green Spaces
reviews: We used to live in Yaletown 20 years ago and it continues to evolve as a trendy neighborhood that has some solid restaurants, terrific sea walk, and great green spaces dotted along the waterfront neighborhood.  Walking to the core of downtown is an easy 15 minute walk. It's a great neighborhood to grab a bite and/or beer before or after a game at Rogers Arena or BC Place. The urban supermarket Urban Fare has a terrific prepared food section and better coffee (and hot chocolate) than the Starbucks next door.

title: Great "High End" place
reviews: Great place for many of Vancouver's best restaurants. Lots of great sushi and seafood places to go out and eat at. Did a bit of a restaurant/bar hop with a friend of mine when I visited.

title: Lively area
reviews: Lively area with plenty of good restaurants and bars. You can also take the aquabus to Granville Island from here.

title: Yaletown
reviews: Vancouver had developed a great deal over last 20 years and Yaletown has been part of that development. Plenty of places to see, eat and also drink. If you get a chance to stop off I would recommend

title: Happening and Hip Yaletown
reviews: Yaletown is the new hip area of Vancouver.  Old warehouses have been turned into cool restaurants, cocktail lounges and local fashion boutiques Just a short walk away is the David Lam Park by the waterfront where you can take a stroll or a bike ride.  Yaletown is the Soho of NY!  Worth a visit!

title: Stroll in Yaletown!
reviews: Recommend to everyone that they need to take a stroll in Yaletown. Enjoy some of the nice shops and restaurants in the area!

title: smart set
reviews: took a your through the streets of Yaletown.This is the area to strive to live in,its beautiful old architecture blends in nicely with the modern.It simply oozes money and class all the way down to its waterfront.

title: If in the area
reviews: If you are visiting Granville Island (and most people do), you will almost certainly pass through Yaletown. Such an area is typical of so man cities today, here warehouses that have largely become largely obsolete, have been replaced with bars, restaurants, clubs and other hip or cool leisure establishments. We just passed through, and you might like to do similar. Unless you're hip or cool!

title: Place for shopping and dining
reviews: Visited yaletown in June and September 2017 for dinner.  Ate at the distillery one night which is a block beside the Canada line station.  Yaletown-roundhouse station is the stop prior to Vancouver city centre on the canada line.  Then ate two blocks from the train station at Brix and mortar.  Actually lots of dining options close to train station.

title: Hip "warehouse"-type district
reviews: Very trendy "hidden" area but with great restaurants.  Some places appear very upscale but we found amazing deals/prices at several eateries.  If you happen to be near here, you should really stroll through!

title: A bit of everything
reviews: Tons of restaurants and bars to satisfy everyone.  Close to the water and water taxis so it is easy to get around.  Bustling at night and on weekends it is a great place to visit more than once.

title: Little bit of this and a little bit of that...
reviews: An area of the City that offers all things to all people and a haunt for young millenials to reside. Has everything - shops, restaurants, entertainment - for everyone (all age groups and prefernces) all close at hand; Gastown, Stadium, transport. Worth a look see and mingle amongst the locals.

title: graet place for restaurants
reviews: Lots and lots of restaurants here - from chains like Earls to independent seafood restaurants - great atmosphere and close to a SkyTrain station - worth a trip there.

title: Lunch
reviews: Yaletown is nice if you stay around the port but after that we were not impressed.  We had lunch in a restaurant and it was nice but nothing more to do.

title: Good part of the town for shopping with plenty of restaurants choice
reviews: This is another interesting part of the city and I have seen plenty of interesting restaurants and nice little shops. Like everywhere in the city you will see a lot of street people barging for money. I have longtime not seen so many poor people in such a short time.

title: Spent ten minutes here!
reviews: We did not understand this area at all. Nothing exciting around, in fact we wondered if we were in the right area. We visited via the ''hop on, hop off' trolley bus. In fact we spent more time waiting for the bus than looking around. We did see some nice restaurants though.

title: Downtown Vancouver
reviews: Yaletown is known for its old warehouse buildings now home to hip restaurants and cocktail lounges, many with buzzing outdoor terraces, as well as indie fashion and decor boutiques. On the waterfront, David Lam Park has an expansive lawn and a playground.

title: Nice relaxing vibrant area with plenty going on
reviews: Well, it is mostly about the restaurants. Wall to wall next door to one another but intermingled on the other side of the street smaller shops and trendy businesses. It is useful to see an old train area with warehouses etc reclaimed to make an interesting area. The restaurants are very good. We tried three on different nights. Each had their own highs but the common theme was people having fun - locals and tourists. Very friendly staff, never to busy to have a quick chat. It all feels safe at night too. We were staying in Hotel Blu on Robson, so it was only a ten minute walk at most. The Keg is great as are they all I'm sure.

title: Great restaurants
reviews: What had been warehouses for the shipping trade are now restaurant after restaurant.  The raised brick walkways make a great place to stroll and pick one to your liking.

title: Great Urban Restaurants!
reviews: There are lots of restaurants in this area.  It is very cute.....many restaurants have outdoor seating in an old railroad type setting.  We loved this area!

title: Good neighborhood especially by the waterfront
reviews: If you're visiting Yaletown definitely go by the Waterfront where there's some open air high end restaurants facing the water with the sailboats and yachts  kind of giving you a south of France feel.

title: The real hipster neighborhood
reviews: This was a nice place to walk around in the evening.  The bars and restaurants came alive.  We enjoyed seeing the crowds!

title: Modern and tasty
reviews: Nice place in Vancouver to admire the modern architecture and the adaptation of the old part od the City to the modern times. A lot of fancy restaurants. God place for walk and leisure.

title: Third time to Vancouver, first time visiting Yaletown
reviews: We walked through Yaletown on the way to the False Creek Ferries. I had not visited Yaletown before and will again. The is a hip, young, gentrified area. Nice shops, eateries, and coffee shops. Lots of yoga and healthy shops.

title: Repurposed area done right
reviews: We walked over from our hotel and found this old warehouse area alive with activity. The streets are filled with remodeled three story buildings full of retail and restaurants on the street level and apartments and professional upstairs. The businesses were modern and local, full of people young and old. The restaurants patrons filled up all the available outside seating on the old loading docks. Nice to see a city getting it right.

title: Wished I had had a bit more time here
reviews: To be honest, I had not expected to visit this area.  But I was dropped off there by my uncle who said that it was a nice place to spend some time, and that the Aquabus made the trip to Granville Island from a nearby pier.  He was right of course...on both counts.  Spent some time looking at the various trendy shops and restaurants that were housed in a combination of older brick buildings and newer constructions.  The waterfront was also a nice place for a stroll and enjoy the views of False Creek and the boats in the marina.  It would have been nice to have had more time, but that will have to wait to the next visit.

title: Nice area to wander round
reviews: We enjoyed visiting Yaletown for an hour or so. We'd already eaten which was disappointing as the restaurants we walked past had some amazing looking food on offer. There are a few unusual shops to look around.

title: A bit residential plus two sports stadia
reviews: A decent enough quarter of Vancouver, but certainly not the most interesting - unless you are interested in sports stadia (there are 2) or Olympic history (the Olympic Village from 2010 is here).

title: great food variety
reviews: This area has really grown up. There are a variety of restaurants, bars and shops and it is a happening place that's close in

title: Young and Stylish in Yaletown
reviews: We had dinner at Blind Pig Yaletown and found it a wonderful place to dine.  Good wine (the Seghisio Zinfindel 2015) and excellent food.  We noticed other restaurants' outdoor tables seated with young people dressed up far more than elsewhere in Vancouver, even on Westside.

title: Must GO
reviews: If you like cool and different places, that's a neighborhood you must go. Thousands of restaurants and small charming boutiques to discover with an funky look.

title: Funky neighborhood
reviews: This neighborhood is an old historic section - buildings have been turned into restaurants, bars, and shops. Great place to dine and walk around.

title: long street
reviews: Yaletown is big and called as Posh location. It has many boutiques, restaurants to hangout. But it is ok to roam around nothing too exciting.

title: City's Old Warehouse District
reviews: A great historical part of the City now converted to loft condos, art galleries, trendy restaurants (see separate reviews), coffee shops and shops.  Walking distance from Robson Street, Granville Street and False Creek by the Roundhouse.

title: Great place to eat
reviews: Old historic town buildings revamped into dining and bars.  Offers a bit of everything but a lively place with good vibes, foods, and desserts.  One of our favorite areas of Vancouver to visits.

title: Staying in Yaletown
reviews: Lots of bars, restaraunts and boutiques, place seems to be vibrant during the daytime so can imagine it to be alive during the evening/night time

title: Not very Exciting
reviews: We were told to wander this area for shopping but found shopping rather limiterd. Must better shopping in Gastown. There are a number of nice outdoor dining spots along the water but not too much else

title: Generic Upscale Neighborhood
reviews: This was an okay walk through.  There are lots of beauty service options and coffee houses.   Cf with Chinatown!

title: Do you like lots of tall buildings all in a row? Then this is for you!
reviews: We walked through here after walking through the nearby West End and the contrast could not have been more stark.  Whereas the streetscapes in the West End were delightful, with beautiful, large mature street trees and restored Victorian style homes, Yaletown seems to be just rows of very tall apartment buildings - maybe architects can tell the difference but they all looked pretty much the same to me.  Add to that tools in fast expensive cars showing off on the streets - frankly I wished I hadn't bothered.

title: Nice trendy/up and coming neighborhood to walk to
reviews: The neighborhood seems to be getting revitalized. Much like the meatpacking district in NY, this area used to be an industrial/warehouse and now has many shops, breweries and restaurants. There seem to be more locals than tourists at this point. Still residential feeling but worth walking by on your way to David Lam to get aqua bus to Granville Island.

title: Residential area, lots of restaurants. Not that interesting a walk, though
reviews: This is largely a residential area, with Street after street of apartment buildings.  There are some good restaurants here, though.That being said, there are more interesting neighborhoods to walk through.

title: Forget it
reviews: Unless you want to just eat/drink the area has little to offer. Filled with various resaurants and bars which might be fun in the evening but not so much during the day.

title: A great place to find a spot for a meal
reviews: I love yaletown! Love the variety of restauarants and shops, and it's not too expensive for the high quality options. Very trendy and fun.

title: Interesting
reviews: Good atmosphere, decent restaurants and cafes.  Interesting buildings.  not far from main shopping areas in downtown Vancouver.  Easy to walk by on way to coast.  Worth a visit.

title: Good
reviews: Lots off good restaurants to eat in not cheap but on par to England 2roads walk down look at menus sure to find something you will like

title: For millennial who don't cook
reviews: Thought there would be some shops to explore. A few. Mostly many eateries. Endless places to eat. Enjoy a brew and people watch if that is your thing

title: Nice area just south of downtown
reviews: Restaurants, bars, different shops and nice buildings, make this a perfect area to spend an afternoon or evening.

title: Beautiful architecture. Very urbanized
reviews: I found it to be like every other city's up and coming neighbourhood.  Drive by, but I wouldn't bother getting out of the tour bus for this.

title: Good place for food and beer at night
reviews: We visited on our first night. A huge range of eateries with an emphasis on catering for the young (or young at heart!). It attracts all sorts. There are the cruisers in their BMW's, the Stag and Hen do's and the old fogies like ourselves all mingling. Check where you eat as some have inordinately loud music - even quite early in the evening. Oh, I defy you to find a place that isn't showing Ice Hockey on multiple screens!!!!!

title: Restaurants, Bars, Bars
reviews: We were here on a beautiful day and there are 2 blocks of restaurant/bars that were packed.  The opposite side of the street had a few shops and other activities, ie. barr.   We felt this was for the 40 and under crowd and everyone appeared to be having a great time.

title: Buzzy ... and sophisticated hot spot .
reviews: Yale town for breakie /// Yale town for  lunch + dinner ..// bars pubs clubs restaurants... Yale town has it all ...Also some nice individual owned shops /// ice cream made in incubators... veggies beautifully grown in trays .. in special fridges.. Canada is very clued in to the ( Green World ) .Great place to stay... we loved Vancouver ... and spent 2 weeks there // and 2 weeks in the Rockies ... fantastic country.

title: Great area full of amazing restaurants
reviews: Have been to this area for business and most recently as part of a 5 day vacation to Vancouver with my wife recently. This is a great area and one in which we ate many of our meals. Great place to walk around, easy to get to and from, clean, felt safer than other areas, close to waterfront, interesting shops and lots of great restaurants. Place I would defiantly recommend going especially to eat.

title: Nice
reviews: Great to walk around old time etc. Modern pubs and eating etc. Just has a nice feel and easy walking

title: Bars restaurants really nice accessible from
reviews: Downtown either by bus train or 15 min walk to waterfront of false creek also has little ferry boats to granville island science world etc Safe at night time pleasant atmosphere nice little store s for shopping boutique hotel close to stadium and hockey place public library etc

title: Very metropolitan.
reviews: An are of the city, once full of sidings and warehouses, but today converted to residential and shopping.  An interesting area to wander around.

title: In the process of urban renewal
reviews: On a recent visit to Vancouver, we stayed on Robson Street but spent a lot of time walking in the Yaletown area, where there is a huge amount of construction going on.  Huge condos and office buildings going in everywhere.  Vibrant area with lots of restaurants and cafes.  We also took the Hop-on Hop-off bus tour through the area.

title: Good neighborhood to wander around
reviews: Yaletown offers a nice range of restaurants from modest to high end.  It's also a residential neighborhood.

title: Fun, great shops and restaurants
reviews: We spent 5 nights in Yaletown and loved it. Great place to walk and shop, grab a meal or drink. You can get exercise walking the sea wall. A very pedestrian city, don't bother trying to drive around.

title: Restaurant Row!
reviews: so many to choose from, get on yelp too to see reviews! ...we had a few beers at the Brewery..(not as good as Seattle)..but fun..to people watch. Homer St Restaurant was fabulous!!

title: Very Upbeat Area - Great For Food
reviews: We walked around Yaletown at around midday as we were meeting a friend for lunch. The area is a more recently developed place with plenty of artisan coffee bars, restaurants and cafes. We had a little walk around to get a feel for the area and there is plenty going on and lots of opportunities to people watch. Just around the corner from False Creek there are plenty of places to sit and take the world in.It is within walking distance from the main areas in downtown however is also accessible from the metro on the Canada line.

title: More than a life style
reviews: From local breweries to awesome cafes and snack bars, Yaletown has it all, even a farmers' market and a Mini dealership. Make sure you check out the local artzy shops and galleries...and if your budget is limited, there is even dollar stores around!

title: We really enjoyed walking around Yaletown!
reviews: Yaletown is a fun mix of great stores, wonderful restaurants and coffee places.  There are really wonderfully built buildings with lovely architecture.  Our hotel was in Yaletown and we found it easy to walk to many places that were really enjoyable.

title: Very nice
reviews: Get your valet ready! This place will get you big time!!! A bit expansive, but you get what you pay for!

title: A pleasant stroll through the city
reviews: Heading back from False Creek to downtown Vancouver we walked through the area know as Yaletown. Originally an industrial area of the city the area was redeveloped after the World Fair of 1986 and bordered by False Creek is now a densely populated area with marinas, parks and apartments. It makes for a pleasant stroll through the city.

title: Interesting Bars, Restaurants, Parks and Urban Planning
reviews: Yaletown is one of Vancouver's recent urban planning developments. It is accessible by transit, including sea bus, or car (reasonable parking). The sea wall was is diverse and well enhanced with public art. As well, there are parks with fascinating sculpture installations. Along Pacific and up to the warehouse district streets are interesting restaurants and fun bars. At night, it's fun here.

title: Cool Place to Wander!
reviews: This quaint neighborhood can be a hidden gem that you don't want to miss.  A bunch of restaurants and bars line an industrial looking street that offer plenty of food & beverage choices.

title: Great place for finding good eats
reviews: My daughter and I dined in Yaletown two evenings during our stay.  One of them was at Manami, a great Japanese restaurant with amazing food!

title: A small city feel in the BIG CITY
reviews: This area of town has a lot of great restaurants, pubs, and other attractions.  Great for a walk around.

title: Station, waterfront and attractions
reviews: Yaletown Roundhouse station is ideal to get to this part of Downtown Vancouver from the airport or the harbour waterfront. A short walk allows the False Creek taxis, stadium, and nearby attractions to be enjoyed.

title: Fun up-and-coming district in downtown
reviews: The old warehouses are being converted into restaurants, shops, workplaces, and apartments.  With a mix of old brick buildings and new construction, the area is vibrant and high energy.

title: A happening place in Vancouver
reviews: Restaurants for every taste and occasion including Rodney's Oyster Bar (a must if you like oysters and other sea foods with a great atmosphere), Bluewater Café for more elegant dining with a great Sushi Bar and great seafood.. I recommend  the Sable Fish at Bluewater (best in town). Also fun places like the Flying Pig Restaurant,,Ciopinno's, and a host of others. Shops, hair salons, and other places to drop in and browse.
